column47:
Internal Quality Control (QC): Verify the accuracy and precision of routine measurements.
Internal control sources: Routine measurement (daily or weekly) of a standard control source.
Assessment of recovery of known activity.
Application of control charts to detect trends.
Duplicates or replicates: Measurement of a duplicate sample to assess repeatability.
Typical criterion: ≤10% difference in results.
Laboratory blanks: Measurement of inert matrices or empty containers to detect contamination or interferences.
Secondary standard sources: Verification of efficiency and calibration against standards traceable to a national agency (IAEA, NIST)

column29: radiochemical method (routine) of Sr-90 determination based on oxalate precipitation of Ca and Sr; heating to oxides and the usage of aluminum as Y-90 carrier. The equilibrium is achieved in 18 days; and after that time Y-90 is isolated on the Al(OH)3 carrier; which is then ignited to an oxide that is subsequently measured by proportional counter.
column31: The laboratory plans to enhance its radioanalytical capacity by acquiring a Hidex 300 SL Liquid Scintillation Counter. It will be used for determination of tritium (³H) and radon (²²²Rn) in water samples, as well as for other low-level radioactivity measurements relevant to environmental monitoring programs, including total alpha/beta activity and low-energy beta emitters such as ¹⁴C and ⁹⁰Sr/⁹⁰Y.

column45: The laboratory uses the following certified reference materials: mixed radionuclide standards supplied by the Czech Metrological Institute, point sources supplied by Amersham, two standards for proportional counter, radionuclide Am-241 and Sr-90 supplied by Czech Metrological Institute, and ALMERA reference materials.
column47: Internal quality control program is composed of day-to-day monitoring of analytical performance. HPGe detectors: Equipment performance is verified on a regular basis, every week, using Gamma Vision Software. Energy calibration in a whole region of energies is checked before applying the QC procedure, which includes measurement of the detector-shield background, total activity, peak shape, and peak drift. These parameters are tracked with warning and acceptance limits (long term trend is analysed). A Co-60 point source is used for that purpose. Results of the QC are stored in a database and can be displayed and charted. Gas proportional counter: before every analytical batch, the background count rate and efficiency of the counter are checked (alpha efficiency with Am-241 and beta with Sr-90/Y-90 source). Gamma-spectrometry method: internal QC covers analysis of control samples - certified reference materials, reference materials or laboratory control samples according to the appropriate plan and program of quality control. Internal quality control method is performed through blank measurements and measurements of a control sample before each set of samples to check the accuracy and precision of the method. For control samples, the Laboratory uses reference materials and samples obtained through ALMERA intercomparison exercises. Sr-90 radiochemical method: internal QC is run with each analytical batch and consists of method blank analysis and analysis of duplicates (additional replicates of samples that are subjected to the same procedure as the original sample). The Laboratory also regularly uses reference materials containing certified amounts of the target radionuclide (LCS) to check the accuracy and precision of the method (whether the results achieved during the validation of the method are maintained).
column49:
Annually
In addition to the annual report, a semi-annual (provisional) report is submitted to the national authority, and any elevated radionuclide activity detected in environmental samples is immediately reported to the Directorate for Radiation Safety and Nuclear Security.
column51: Routine monitoring data are reported to the national database MONRADRS (Environmental Radioactivity Monitoring in the Republic of Serbia), which is maintained by the Directorate for Radiation Safety and Nuclear Security (SRBATOM). Data from MONRADRS are subsequently transmitted to regional and international databases under EURATOM/IAEA reporting obligations.

column59: The network includes: 7 stations sampling air continuously; 9 stations sampling solid and liquid precipitations continuously; 7 stations sampling soil once per year; 6 stations analyzing surface water with gamma spectrometry monthly; 4 stations analyzing surface water with gamma spectrometry 4 times per year; 2 stations analyzing Sr-90 and H-3 in surface water monthly; 10 locations measuring sediment twice per year; 7 locations measuring drinking water daily; 7 stations measuring milk daily; 7 stations measuring food twice per year; 3 stations measuring mixed food (from kindergartens) three times a year; 7 stations measuring feedstuff twice a year.
column60: The question falls under the competence of the national regulatory authority (SRBATOM), which operates the national early warning and automatic monitoring network. To the best of our knowledge, such systems exist in Serbia but are not operated directly by our laboratory.
column66: Countrywide, on a regular basis: monitoring of radioactivity in the territory of the City of Belgrade. NORM industry: monitoring of radioactivity in the vicinity of thermal power plants. Other: monitoring of radioactivity in the Danube river ecosystem.

column69:
ΕΝRACT has participated in a number of projects funded by European and national programs. In addition, since 2007 it operates the Demokritos Regional Research Aerosol station, member of the Global Atmosphere Watch (GAW) and ACTRIS networks and since 2016 the Helmos Mt Free Troposphere Aerosol and Climate Change station in Western Greece. Since 2001 it operates instrumentation for measurements and data analysis at the IASOA, GAW and ACTRIS Zeppelin station, Ny Aalesund Svalbard in the European High Arctic for monitoring Black Carbon and Aerosol absorption.
ΕΝRACT has organised and implemented several measurement campaigns for the characterization of urban particulate pollution, the identification of the major emission sources and the quantification of their contribution to concentration levels, as well as the assessment of the respective impact on human health. In the framework of recent research projects on urban air quality, ΕΝRACT has enhanced the capacity of local, regional and national authorities, by providing evidence on air pollution levels and sources, transferring know-how and experience and providing tools for effective urban air quality management.
ΕΝRACT is the only Laboratory, to which GAEC (EAEE) has assigned the continuous control of environmental radioactivity in Greece. The provision of this national service satisfies the obligations provided by the Greek Legislation on Radiation Protection and the relevant EU Regulations.

column59: Gamma dose rate: PC + GM tube, one measuring point, monthly. Environmental TLD: 5 measuring points, 2 times per year. Air monitoring: one sampling and measuring point, monthly. Precipitation: one sampling and measuring point, monthly. Drinking water from public water supply: 4 measuring points (towns) 2 times per year, measuring gamma spectrometry, Rn-222, H3, total alpha and beta. Skadar Lake water: one measuring point, 2 times per year. Seawater: 2 sampling and measuring points, 2 times per year. River water: 8 rivers sampled once per year. Soil, cultivated and uncultivated: 6 sampling and measuring points, once per year. Food: practically all types of food intended for human consumption are analysed separately by gamma spectrometry + Sr-90 in mixed diet samples. Frequency: once per year from 8 towns in Montenegro. Feed (animal food): 6 types of samples once per year. Building materials: 7 types of samples once per year. Radon and Thoron (Rn-222 and Rn-220) in dwellings.

column45: Reference materials from internationally recognized laboratories (e.g. NIST traceable standards).
column47:
Some of the main aspects are listed below. 
- A fundamental aspect regarding quality assurance of measurements is the regular participation in intercomparison exercises or proficiency test programs organized by laboratories with international recognition (International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), National Physical Laboratory (NPL), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). 
- Calibration of the measurement systems according to each laboratory using calibration sources or certified reference materials from internationally recognized laboratories. 
- Preparation of control charts to verify that equipments measure correctly. 
- Verification of background measurements for the measurement system. 
- Verification of detection limit of techniques in case of bakground variation. 
- Recording of technical maintenance carried out regularly. 
- Verification of robustness by using NIST traceable standards, when changing for example the batch of Liquid Scintillation Counter cocktails. 
- Verification of micropipettes used. 
- Determination of chemical efficiency for sample batches, for example for Sr-90 analysis. 
- For techniques that are validated, a validation of the method will be carried out in successive stages by laboratory analysts, evaluating the following variables according to the experimental results obtained in terms of: Accuracy, Intermediate Accuracy, Repeatability, Reproducibility , Robustness, Minimum Detectable Concentration. 
- Accreditation of laboratories under ISO 17025 Standard started in 2006 to demonstrate that there is a quality management system and the laboratories are technically competent to generate valid results.
The Environmental Control Laboratory has the following techniques accredited under ISO 17025 Standard: Determination of gamma emitters in waters; Determination of uranium in waters by fluorimetry and kinetic phosphorescence; Determination of tritium in waters and milk and the Determination of Strontium-90 in waters.

column59: Air and dose rate sampling stations around NPP belong to licensees, and ARN verifies the monitoring. ARN has 1 station in the atomic centre (radioisotopes production facility and fuel fabrication) for aerosols and gaseous iodine, and a background station for aerosols and humidity condensate monitoring.
column63: Around NPP and atomic centres with TLD detectors, not automatically.
column66: Emergency exposure situations: ad-hoc monitoring is prepared (air monitoring, soil, water, milk and food samples, dose rate monitoring). Around nuclear facilities: aerosols monitoring (annually); dose rate (integrated every six months); humidity condensates (weekly); milk (monthly); soils and sediments (annually); food (sampled monthly and measured every 3 months as pools); fish (sampled monthly and measured every six months as pools); waters (monthly). Existing exposure situations (e.g. uranium legacy sites): uranium sites are not considered legacy sites as they are under regulatory control. Environmental monitoring is performed once a year (uranium and Ra-226 analysis in waters (surface, drinking waters, aquifer) and radon emantion rate from the tales). Also radon in air in the surroundings and dwellings.

column19:
GLP Laboratórios specializes in ionizing radiation testing. It was founded in 2015 with the goal of becoming a leading private laboratory in the field of radiometric testing, boasting state-of-the-art equipment for a variety of ionizing radiation tests. GLP offers a broad range of radiometric analysis services and operates in the food, environmental, mining, oil and gas, and research and development sectors. Its main areas of activity are:

-Alpha Spectrometry
-Gamma Spectrometry
-Liquid Scintillation
-Gaseous Flow Proportional Counter
-Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry

The laboratory is accredited by the INMETRO General Accreditation Coordination Office according to ABNT NBR ISO/IEC 17025:2017, under CRL 1266. It is a research laboratory accredited by ANSN - National Nuclear Safety Authority, to operate as a Radiation Facility, under registration number 17525, and for analytical techniques, under registration number 18309.

column29: Using membrane treatment technology to rapidly remove ions from water to meet the pretreatment requirements for tritium measurement, thereby achieving rapid detection of tritium in water.
column30: For the rapid detection of trace radioactive cesium ions in water, especially in seawater, we have applied a self-developed membrane material that can rapidly and selectively adsorb and retain radioactive cesium ions.
column31: Using rapid membrane technology to replace traditional pretreatment methods such as low-efficiency distillation, ion exchange, and adsorption.
column32: In the future, the technology of "rapid enrichment of radioactive ions in water using membrane methods" will advance in the directions of material precision, process intelligence, system integration, and application scenario-specific development. At the material level, it will shift from general-purpose membranes to specialized membranes "tailor-made" for specific radioactive ions. The separation process will evolve from passive filtration to intelligent separation that is actively responsive and controllable. System design will also progress from single membrane components to integrated equipment combining pretreatment, enrichment, detection, and regeneration functions. In terms of application, it will further expand from laboratory research to customized solutions for different water bodies (such as seawater, wastewater, and groundwater) and diverse usage needs (such as emergency response, real-time monitoring, and resource recovery).

column19: We are all nuclear physicists by background. 5 of us have PhDs in nuclear physics and we are professors of fundamental and applied nuclear physics courses, as well as medical physics and nuclear physics (Nuclear Physics Group). One PhD student is employed as a member of our group and beside him we have 6 active PhD students that members of our group are supervising. We are closely collaborating with Department of Chemistry at our Faculty for complicate sample preparation techniques.

column29:
1. LSC method for Sr90 in water by Cherenkov counting
2. Fast gross alpha/beta screening method
3. Rn-222 in water on LSC
4. Modified ISO method for uranium in water measurements by LSC
5. Ra-226 on LSC
6. Sr-90 in milk samples by microwave digestion sample preparation and LSC measurement via Cherenkov counting
7. The use of efficiency transfer software for gamma spectrometry for low energy radioisotopes
8. The use of ionic liquids to improve the efficiency of detection for different alpha and beta emitters on LSC
9. C-14 in waste water samples with LSC without complicate chemical preparation
etc.
column30: Swipe sample analysis on LSC
column31:
Further testing of the possibilities to use ionic liquids in LSC measurements.
Improvement of results for HPGe measurements of samples containing uranium.
The use of mathematical calculations, simulations and AI in gamma spectrometry for the analysis of nuclear and other radioactive materials.
column32: Since we don't have radiochemistry lab for sample preparation most of the methods that we develop are relatively fast since the sample preparation is usually minimal. At the moment we don't have exact plans of development of new rapid methods for particular radioisotopes but we are open for any proposals.

column19: Their areas of expertise include the determination of gross alpha and gross beta activity in water samples, the determination of tritium in water samples by distillation method, and gamma spectrometric analysis of water samples.
column20:
Our laboratory requires assistance in obtaining expert support for analytical techniques related to gross alpha/beta, tritium, and gamma spectrometric analysis, as well as access to advanced analytical instruments and finanial support for staff participation in relevant international training programmes.
In addition, the laboratory has occasionally encountered challenges in achieving satisfactory results in inter-laboratory comparison tests. Therefore, we would greatly appreciate expert assistance in evaluating and improving the measurement uncertainty in radiological analysis to enhance the accuracy and reliability of our results. 
Looking ahead, the laboratory also aims to expand its analytical capabilities in the field of environmental monitoring. Support in this area - including technical guidance, capacity building, and access to appropriate analytical tools - would be highly valuable for our future development.

column45:
The laboratory uses reference materials (RMs) and standard sources for calibration and quality control purposes. These include:
•Standard gamma sources (Multinuclide Standard Source) such as Cs-137 and Co-60 for energy and efficiency calibration of the HPGe gamma spectrometry system.
•Americium-241 (Am-241) for efficiency calibration.
•Strontium-90 (Sr-90) for efficiency calibration.
•Quenched H-3 Standards Set (10 vials) for efficiency calibration.
•Unquenched Liquid Scintillation Standards Set (C-14, H-3, and background) for calibration and performance verification of the liquid scintillation counting system.
column47:
The laboratory has established internal QA/QC procedures to ensure the reliability and accuracy of measurement results. These include:
•
Routine instrument performance checks and energy/efficiency calibration using standard sources.
•
Background and stability checks performed periodically.
•
Analysis of quality control samples and duplicates to verify measurement precision and accuracy.
•
Regular participation in internal cross-check measurements among laboratory personnel.
•
Maintenance and calibration records maintained according to the laboratory’s quality manual.
column59: A network of sampling stations were carefully selected and several requirements were taken into consideration during the site selection to ensure that environmental samples from those areas would be appropriate representatives. Such network has been established for installing high volume air samplers, fallout containers, and OSLs to collect air particulates, fallout, and radiation doses, respectively, and for sampling other terrestrial and marine environmental samples for radioactivity measurement.
column61: The national early warning radiation monitoring network has been well established both for airborne and seawater monitoring using NaI detectors and GM probes. The network consists of 22 airborne stations installed and operated across the country, and 1 seawater probe in the Andaman Sea. Several technical criteria and infrastructure readiness, such as internet connection, site security, natural disaster, site access, were well taken into consideration when siting. Gamma dose rates and identified gamma-emitting radionuclide data are transmitted in nearly real-time to the national data center at Office of Atoms for Peace for further data analysis. Data from several selected stations have been shared the ASEAN Radiation Data Exchange Platform (ASEAN-RDEP) and IAEA International Radiation Monitoring Information System (IRMIS) to ensure timely notification and to provide supporting data to ASEAN MSs and IAEA MSs for more effective decision making process during a nuclear or radiological emergency. OAP is planning to install and operate the Noble Gas Detection System early 2026 under the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT).
column63:
There is a gamma dose rate monitoring network operational in the country
There is an environmental monitoring network of automatic monitors for gamma-ray spectrometry of aerosols and/or for gaseous iodine in the laboratory's country
The national early warning radiation monitoring network has been well established both for airborne and seawater monitoring using NaI detectors and GM probes. The network consists of 22 airborne stations installed and operated across the country, and 1 seawater probe in the Andaman Sea. Several technical criteria and infrastructure readiness, such as internet connection, site security, natural disaster, site access, were well taken into consideration when siting. Gamma dose rates and identified gamma-emitting radionuclide data are transmitted in nearly real-time to the national data center at Office of Atoms for Peace for further data analysis. Data from several selected stations have been shared the ASEAN Radiation Data Exchange Platform (ASEAN-RDEP) and IAEA International Radiation Monitoring Information System (IRMIS) to ensure timely notification and to provide supporting data to ASEAN MSs and IAEA MSs for more effective decision-making process during a nuclear or radiological emergency.
column64: The results are recorded in the database manually after a careful review by the experienced data analyst.
column66: The national radiation monitoring program has been established and is being implemented on a routine basis. Environmental samples such as air particulate, fallout, soil, sediment, fresh water, seawater, and grass, and food including milk, rice, vegetables, meats, and seafood (fish, squid, mussel, and shrimp) are collected from various areas across the country with close collaboration with other governmental agencies and universities. Radioactivity from natural and artificial radionuclides in those samples are measured using HPGe Gamma Spectrometry, LSC, Alpha Spectrometry, and Proportional Counters. In addition, radiation dose rates are measured using OSLs. Radiation dose and radiological risk assessment are performed using radioactivity data in conjunction with other site specific data, such as consumption and inhalation rates, and predictive models. Obtained data are recorded in the database for future use both in peace time and in a nuclear or radiological emergency.
column67: Priority radionuclides include Cs-137, Co-60, K-40, H-3, Sr-90, and natural radionuclides (U-238, Th-232, Ra-226). Preferred matrices are soil, water, and food (e.g., rice, vegetables, and milk powder).

column59: Following EU legislation, there is an Environmental Radiological Surveillance Net around our territory (Spain). The Legal Authority ( CSN) funds this network. The universities and research institutions in our country take samples and measure radionuclides. There are more than 14 stations in REM- NET.  The type of samples and frequency are established. The stations take samples of soil, sediment, air, biota, and food. Mainly they measure Cs137, gross alpha, gross beta, I-131, and Sr90.

Precipitation collectors sampling monthly are located in Graz, Bregenz, Innsbruck, Linz, Salzburg, Eisenstadt, Klagenfurt, Retz, Wien. Surface waters are sampled at the following locations: Mur/Spielfeld (cont.), Mur/Spielfeld monthly, Bodensee/Bregenz every 2 months (6 per year), Inn/Erl monthly, Inn/Martinsbruck monthly, Rhein/Bangs every 2 months (6 per year), Rhein/Fußach monthly, Donau/Aschach monthly, Donau/Jochenstein monthly, Drau/Schwabegg continuously, Drau/Schwabegg monthly, Inn/Ingling monthly, Lavant/Lavamünd monthly, Salzach/Oberndorf monthly, Donau/Jochenstein quarterly (once every three months), March/Hohenau (STRA) weekly, Donau/Hainburg monthly, Donau/Nussdorf monthly, Leitha/Nickelsdorf monthly, March/Hohenau monthly, March/Markthof monthly, Thaya/Alt-Prerau monthly, Thaya/Bernhardsthal monthly. Drinking water is sampled monthly at the following locations: Graz, Innsbruck, Linz, Bregenz, Eisenstadt, Klagenfurt, St. Pölten, Salzburg, Wien. Mixed drinking water samples are taken in Wien every 3 months (4 per year). Milk (Cow) samples are taken every two months (6 samples per year) at the following locations: Aflenz, Bleiburg, Eibiswald, Kötschach-Mautern, Spittal a/d Drau,  Obersaifen, Reichenfelsh, Deutschlandsberg, Feldkirch, Kals, Möggers, Pinswang, Schwoich, Telfs, Waidring, Zell am Ziller, Ampflwang, Ebensee, Elixhausen, St.Johann im Pongau, Feldkirchen, Maishofen, Mittersill, Oberes Mühlviertel, Pruggern, Reichraming, Reichraming, Schardenberg, Horitschon, Oberwart, Reichenau, Traunstein, Ulmerfeld, Ampflwang. column39: The QMS programme is based on calibration using reference materials, inter-laboratory comparisons, and scheduled calibrations performed by engineers.
column45: The standard reference source material (Catalog No. 7500, Source No 586-26-6) used in the laboratory is produced by the Isotope Products Laboratories, USA.
column47:
1. Efficiency Calibration: Using Laboratory Sourceless Calibration Software (LabSOCS) for efficiency calibration, which models the detector response based on the sample's chemical composition and geometry.
2. Inter-laboratory Comparison: Collaborating with the State Key Laboratory of Environmental Geochemistry (SKLEG/IGC, CAS) to perform parallel measurements and correct the HPGe gamma-spectrometry system efficiency.
3. Use of Certified Reference Material: Employing a standard reference source material (Catalog No. 7500 from the Isotope Products Laboratories, USA) containing the fallout radionuclides (FRNs) of interest.
4. Proficiency Testing: Participation in international proficiency tests organized by the IAEA to validate the laboratory's performance and ensure the accuracy of determination results.
5. Standardized Sample Preparation: Implementing a consistent sample preparation protocol (air-drying, sieving, weighing, and packing into standardized Plexiglass containers) to minimize introduced variability.

column59: There are around 30 sampling stations for environmental purposes. There are also different sampling stations around NPPs and other nuclear facilities. There are different surveillance programmes, all controlled by the CSN. Sampling frequency depends on the surveillance programme, ranging from once a week to once a year (see CSN webpage: https://www.csn.es).

column29:
-We participated in EURAMET EMRP ENV57 project (European Metrology Research Project), with 16 Metrology Institutes and Organisations, to develop faster, more reliable and traceable measurement procedures for airborne radioactivity concentration, dose rate and ground contamination data in routine operation as well as in the case of radiological emergency. In the related work package of the project, faster, more accurate and reliable methods to determine activity concentrations of U, Th, Pu, Sr radioisotopes and Am-241 in air filters were developed. In addition, the effectiveness of a Compton suppression detector system in lowering the minimum detectable activity of 241Am in air filters was evaluated and the counting statistics with the suppression counting mode was improved.
-Rapid determination of strontium-90 in seawater with proportional counters.
-A modified method for rapid determination of Y-90 in seawater with liquid scintillation counting.
-Validation of a newly adopted chemical method for determination of 226Ra and 228Ra activities in water and shrimp samples.
-Synthesis and characterisation of CaAlg polymer by gamma radiation, investigation of optimum adsorption-desorption conditions and its use as adsorbent in determination of 210Pb activity
column30: -Development of Dowex/HBr/HNO3 Extraction Chromatographic Method for Determination of 210Pb Activity with Proportional Counter

column47: Any analytical equipment (eq. HPGe, LSC, ICP) are checked before analyzing routine samples (1st level QC). Any routine samples in a batch are measured with a QA sample in parallel (reference material or old PT sample) (2nd level QC). For each analytical procedure under accreditation or under development, the laboratory participates in proficiency tests (around 120 parameters are tested annually) (3rd level QC). Each batch of sample is validated by a technical responsible. Each test report is reviewed by the labo supervisor before release to the customer.

column20:
A) On-the-Job-Training (OJT) in IAEA partner laboratories around one to three (1-3) months OJT program in the field of Environmental Radioactivity Measurment and Monitoring.

B) On-the-Job-Training (OJT, around 1-3 months) in IAEA Partner Laboratories and Capacity-building activities in the following areas:
•	Sampling, radiochemical processing, and measurement of various radionuclides (e.g., Tritium, Stronium-90, Plutonium) in various environmental media
•	Setting-up, operation, maintenance (including basic troubleshooting), and analysis of radionuclides using gamma spectrometer, liquid scintillation counter, and alpha spectrometer
•	Establishment, operation, maintenance, and analysis using in-situ radioactivity measurement techniques (in-situ gamma ray spectrometry, in-situ monitoring of radioactivity in aquatic and marine waters, stationary air monitoring)
•	Radioactivity data analysis (statistical treatment) and dose estimation

Radiation Physics / Health Physics (Radiation detection principles and dosimetry, 
 Calibration and use of instruments (NaI and HPGe detectors), Shielding calculations and exposure assessment;  
Environmental Science / Environmental Monitoring (Environmental sampling methods (air, water, soil, biota),  
Field monitoring techniques and in-situ measurements; Interpretation of environmental radioactivity data ; Data Analysis / Computational Modeling (Spectral analysis and radionuclide identification,
 Dose modeling and dispersion modeling, use of Software tools-Genie 2000); Implementation of QA/QC protocols (ISO/IEC 17025); Rapid environmental sampling,
  Emergency dose estimation and protective measures.

i  Advanced training on new or specialized analytical techniques (e.g., alpha spectrometry, mass spectrometry like ICP-MS, liquid scintillation counting, XRF for sample composition analysis),

iii Training in radiochemical separation methods and sample preparation protocols, 
iv Field sampling techniques for different environmental matrices
v Assistance in implementing and maintaining ISO/IEC 17025 accreditation or equivalent,
vi Training in innovative monitoring techniques, such as remote sensing or real-time monitoring,
vii Training on laboratory information management systems (LIMS),

column69:
Regarding Section 7.1:
As the Roshydromet network, we conduct regular environmental radioactivity monitoring around nuclear facilities, outside the supervised area, within a 100-kilometer radius.
Kindly note that our measurement techniques involve analyzing the ash residue of a filter material, which consists of polymer fibers applied to a fabric (gauze) substrate used for air sampling.

column31:
•  Lower MDAs & faster TAT: Optimize sample prep and counting to reduce detection limits and deliver rapid EPR screens.
•  Automation & throughput: Introduce autosamplers/enrichment skids (LSC), automated resin cleanup (alpha-spec), and batch workflows for HPGe/ICP-OES/XRF.
•  Geometry/matrix harmonization: Standardize counting geometries and matrix corrections (density/self-absorption) across γ-spec and XRF.
•  Robust calibrations: Maintain geometry-matched CRMs/check sources, hybrid efficiency curves (HPGe), and matrix-matched XRF/ICP calibrations with routine verification.
•  Cross-tech confirmation: Establish targeted cross-checks (e.g., U by α-spec ↔ ICP-OS; γ-spec ↔ XRF where applicable).
•  Uncertainty & QC: Method-specific uncertainty budgets, control charts, and corrective-action tracking aligned to ISO/IEC 17025.

Environmental Sampling: One person is responsible with some support of other person

column45:
The laboratory uses IAEA reference materials, certified radionuclide standards, and traceable calibration sources for gamma spectrometry and other radioanalytical measurements.
Examples include:
IAEA-327, IAEA-CU-2006-02, IAEA-TEL-2018-03, SRM4927 …
Certified beta emitter tracer: Strontium-90 (Yttrium-90)
Certified alpha emitter tracer: Polonium-209
IAEA MRC: Moss-soil 447
IAEA MRC: Phosphogypse 434
column47: In accordance with ISO/IEC 17025 requirements

column66: In addition to the CNESTEN’s Environmental Monitoring Programme,  a National Environmental Monitoring Programme is established by the Moroccan Agency for Nuclear & Radiological Safety & security (AMSSNurR).
column67:
The priority matrices for future proficiency testing (PT) and reference materials (RM) include:
•	Mining and phosphate matrices and their derivatives
•	Biological matrices
•	Food matrices
•	Water and seawater (Gamma & Apha Spectrometry and Tritium)
•	Vegetal matrices (Gamma & Apha Spectrometry)
•	Soil matrices

Radionuclides: Isotopes of Thorium, Uranium and Radium
column68:
The requested activities to be organised by the ALMERA network include:
•	Proficiency testing (PT) exercises for environmental samples (water, soil, vegetation, food, biological matrices) and matrix from mines and miling industry
•	Interlaboratory comparison (ILC) studies for key radionuclides
•	Provision of reference materials (RMs) for calibration and quality assurance
•	Training and capacity-building workshops for participating laboratories
Data evaluation and performance reporting to monitor laboratory proficiency

Online training and webinars where possible as it provides a good opportunity for more people to participate. 
Existing gamma spectrometry webinars have been particularly useful. 
Online training on radiochemistry principles and advanced techniques; alpha spectrometry; LSC analysis and quench corrections.
column69: For future PTs it would be helpful if samples being sent to Australia were dispatched earlier. The sample shipment to ANSTO which was dispatched from Seibersdorf in early July arrived in Australia nearly a month later on 6 Aug 2025 and required further irradiation because Australian customs/quarantine require 50 kGy irradiation and PT samples are treated prior to shipment at 25 kGy. The PT shipment was released to ANSTO after irradiation on 20 Aug leaving 6 weeks for multiple analyses.

column29: We are currently developing a device for foodstuff measurement and sorting in of post-accidental situation. We already performed the proof of concept of this device with a prototype, and we are ready to sign a contract with a manufacturer and for an all-in-one device by the end of October 2025. It will include spectral unmixing algorithms for fast response in preparedness for radiological emergency.

column47:
All
We have either produced in-house or purchased appropriate Quality Control materials that are run with every analytical batch whether accredited or not, with the exception of some very short lived nuclides. 
We run certified standards with every analytical batch to both assure the efficacy of the process, analytical and counting equipment.
Counting equipment is regularly recalibrated against either certified reference sources or specific geometries spiked with known amounts of relevant radionuclides.

column19: The laboratory is a calibration and assay laboratory that is part of a bigger organization with 90 full-time workers mostly dedicated to produce radiopharmaceuticals and specialized services for the Cuban Health Services and the biotechnology industry. There are 3 full-time working professionals in the laboratory. One of them a physicist trained for the scope of radioactivity measurements performed by the laboratory that was listed in 1.14 and two young radiochemists that are under training at present.

column59: Information about the exposure dose rate is transmitted to the laboratory from 42 stations in the national network of observations and laboratory control (SLCK) throughout the Republic of Uzbekistan. 6. Sustainable management of liquid nitrogen supply and preventive maintenance of analytical instruments.

column45:
The laboratory has previously received and used IAEA reference materials and standards for calibration and performance verification, particularly during the period 2006–2014 when the HPGe gamma spectrometry system was active.

Currently, no recent reference materials are in use, as the spectrometry system is non-operational. The laboratory intends to acquire new IAEA or certified reference materials once the equipment is restored and liquid nitrogen supply is re-established.

column66:
Yes. Environmental radioactivity monitoring in Kenya is also undertaken through several programmes coordinated by national institutions:

KNRA: Oversees national environmental radiation monitoring and dose assessment to the public, including baseline surveys around potential radiation sources and border monitoring using Radiation Portal Monitors (RPMs).

Kenya Meteorological Department (KMD): Participates in atmospheric monitoring and emergency preparedness under the national radiation emergency response framework.

National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA): Coordinates environmental surveillance and environmental impact assessments for licensed facilities.

Kenya Bureau of Standards (KEBS) and Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI): Occasionally undertake radioanalytical testing of food, water, and materials for compliance and research purposes.

IAEA-supported projects (e.g. RAF/7/011, INT/9/263) have also contributed to regional environmental monitoring and capacity building.

column68: None requested so far. The laboratory has not identified specific activities but is interested in future ALMERA training, intercomparison exercises, and technical support once operations resume.
column69: KNRA appreciates the continued support of the ALMERA network in strengthening environmental radioactivity monitoring capabilities. Although the national laboratory is currently not fully operational, this survey provides an important opportunity to assess existing capacities and identify future areas for collaboration, training, and technical assistance.

column45: Certified standard solutions purchased from Radioisotope Centre POLATOM (when available) or from foreign laboratories (NPL, Czech Metrology Institute, NIST…) are used. Certified reference materials (e.g. Moss soil, IAEA 447; Billberry powder containing Sr-90, IRMM) are also used if they are available and achievable. Sometimes samples obtained during laboratory intercomparisons are also used to run some tests.
column47: For each new developed method the validation parameters (such as linearity, repeatability, trueness, selectivity, etc.) are determined using certified reference solutions, or, where possible, certified reference materials. The laboratory takes part in national and international proficiency tests at least once in every accreditation cycle--that is, once every four years--for each accredited method used. The laboratory also takes part in proficiency tests for non-accredited methods. Reproducibility tests (intra-laboratory) are also run for accredited methods according to the annual schedule. The measuring equipment--Liquid Scintillation Counter counters, gas-flow proportional counters, alpha spectrometer, gamma spectrometry systems(?)--are tested and calibrated with appropriate reference sources and solutions (control charts are also run and kept). Other equipment: Laboratory balances are calibrated by an external company (most often the balance manufacturer service) with certified weights. Some are also legalised by the Polish national metrology authority (Central Office of Measures), which certifies that the measuring instrument meets the requirements. Internal testing is also performed before each weighing. Automatic pipettes are calibrated internally according to the manufacturer’s instructions (in compliance with EN ISO 8655 standard) by gravimetric method using a balance with appropriate sensitivity. The pH-meters are tested with buffer solutions of a known pH value and calibrated with certified pH-buffer solutions.

column61: There is a network of: 13 ASS-500 stations owned by the Central Laboratory of Radiological Protection, that continuously sample atmospheric aerosols on filters and perform spectrometric determination of the content of individual radioisotopes on a weekly basis. There are also 9 stations operated by the Institute of Meteorology and Water Management (IMiGW), 7 of which conduct the continuous measurement of ambient gamma dose rate and the continuous measurement of total and artificial alpha and beta activity of atmospheric aerosols. The stations also measure total beta activity in 24-hour and monthly samples of total fallout, and  determine the content of Cs-137 (by a spectrometric method) and Sr-90 (by a radiochemical method) in cumulative monthly samples of total fallout from all 9 stations once a month.
column63: There is a national network of early warning stations for radiation contamination, consisting of the 13 ASS-500 stations described in the previous section, as well as 58 automatic Permanent Monitoring Stations (PMS) managed by PAA which operate under the international systems of the EU and of the Baltic Sea States. These stations conduct ongoing measurements of the power of the spatial dose equivalent H*(10), ambient gamma dose rate and spectrum caused by radioactive elements in the air and in the ground, and basic weather parameters (precipitation and ambient temperature). The 9 stations of the Institute of Meteorology and Water Management (IMiGW) also conduct continuous measurements of ambient gamma dose rate and take measurements of the activity of atmospheric aerosols and total precipitation. There are also 13 auxiliary stations of the Ministry of National Defence (MON) that perform measurements of ambient gamma dose rate.
column66:
Emergency exposure situations: 
in cases of radiation emergency, intervention measures are taken based on whether the incident is occurring within the area of a given organizational unit (on-site emergency incidents), or for those incidents with impacts reaching beyond the organizational unit ('regional' and 'national' emergency incidents, including those of cross-border effects). The head of the given entity, a provincial governor or a minister of the interior are in charge of eliminating the hazard and the consequences of the incident, depending on the scale of emergency.  
Around nuclear facilities: radiological monitoring on the premises and in the vicinity of the Świerk Nuclear Centre is conducted by our laboratory (that is, the Radiation Protection Measurements Laboratory of the National Centre for Nuclear Research) according to a monitoring programme approved by the President of PAA. There are additional independent specialized centres selected annually by the President of PAA in the vicinity of the Centre which also carry out monitoring duties. Radiological monitoring on the premises and in the vicinity of the National Radioactive Waste Repository (KSOP) is conducted by the Radioactive Waste Management Plant and by the nearby laboratory commissioned by the PAA’s President. 
Existing exposure situations (e.g. uranium legacy sites): the 'Program of radiological monitoring of areas degraded due to uranium ore extraction and processing' has been implemented at the former uranium ore plants since 1998. In 2018 the following measures were undertaken: measurements of radioactive alpha and beta isotopes in drinking water (from public water intakes) within the territory managed by the Association of Municipalities of the Karkonosze Region, as well as in surface and underground water (outflows from underground workings); and the determination of radon concentration in water from public intakes, in water supplied to residential premises, and in surface and underground water (outflows from underground workings).
